awd_titl_txt: Lefschetz Fibrations, Their Noncommutative Counterparts, and Formal Groups
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to integrate recent insights, originating from theoretical physics, into classical areas of geometry. One can consider these purely mathematical questions as a "theoretical laboratory", which allows one to quickly explore the structure of cutting-edge ideas, abstracting away the full complexity of their physical origin. Besides the expected scientific benefit, the project contains specific parts designed for graduate and undergraduate research. Undergraduate research is an increasingly important part of the training of next-generation scientists and mathematicians.  A particular effort has been made in this project to find issues of current relevance which allow students to take charge, under suitable mentorship.

In Kontsevich's formulation of the string theory notion of mirror symmetry, this becomes a relation between symplectic geometry and algebraic geometry, formulated in a common algebraic language of noncommutative geometry. The project intends to further develop noncommutative geometry thinking in symplectic geometry. This is useful as an organizing principle for the information arising from pseudo-holomorphic curve methods. In the framework of the project, it will lead to new methods for understanding and computing that information. One key question under consideration is the  dependence of categorical structures on the Novikov parameter. Mirror symmetry also has an arithmetic aspect. That motivates another part of the project, which is to bring structures common in number theory, such as formal groups, to bear on symplectic geometry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The project had a central aim and several secondary ones, all located in one of the parts of topology (symplectic topology as pioneered by Floer and Gromov) which has been heavily influenced by a duality (mirror symmetry) proposed by string theorists. One can be interested in this for several reasons: for mathematicians, string theory provides a new viewpoint which can lead to unexpected insights into purely topological problems (this is very much the PI's perspective); on the other hand, one can view these mathematical developments as important supporting evidence for the fundamental correctness and consistency of the far-reaching theoretical ideas of string theory.

A groundbreaking proposal by Kontsevich from the 1990s was to understand mirror symmetry in terms of noncommutative geometry (associative algebras, their generalizations, and associated invariants). In particular, many notions from classical algebraic geometry (hyperplane sections, pencils) should have noncommutative counterparts, which would be fundamental in symplectic topology. The existence of these structures can be studied independently of the original string theory motivation. Indeed, the project's aim was to set them up in intrisic symplectic topology terms, without using mirror symmetry, and to use them for far-reaching structural results. This aim was mostly but not completely achieved (the paper that achieves the main goal exists in preprint form, but two minor papers which provide supporting technical results have not been completed yet). Given the overall size of the project (whose beginning precede this grant, and which is articulated in 8 papers totalling more than 500 pages), this is quite a satisfactory state, and full completion can be reasonably anticipated in the near future.

The other goals were to investigate number theoretic (meaning, aspects that concern specific integer congruences) and homotopical (meaning, belonging to homotopy theory rather than algebra) aspects of Floer theory and mirror symmetry. The first direction has been achieved as planned: the main relevant paper has been accepted for publication, a supporting technical paper is already published, and more work by the PI's graduate students is underway. In the other direction, a promising start was made (overcoming significant conceptual difficulties), again by a graduate student working under the PI's supervision; this is available as a PhD thesis, but has not yet entered the published literature.

Training PhD students has been the main contribution of this project to the development of the scientific workforce. A secondary contribution was made by developing innovative undergraduate curricular material in geometry, and by supervising undergraduate research.

 


Last Modified: 08/12/2022
Modified by: Paul Seidel
